text: Patient: It’s not bad is it? Doctor: I mean I don’t think it’s worse, but it’s not getting better. Family Member: So would that lesion affect his legs also, is it the same stem you know nerve system? Doctor: You know usually not. Family Member: Okay. Doctor: Because I mean hopefully – the arm nerves are on the outside. Family Member: Okay. Doctor: Okay so the leg nerves are running further down. Family Member: Okay. Doctor: But I mean technically yes, if there is a clean total cut of the cord or major pressure at that level, it can affect the arms and the legs. Family Member: Yeah. Patient: Because I have pain walking upstairs. Doctor: Sort of the Christopher Reeve’s spot –

text: Patient: Okay. Doctor: Now, the computer flips a coin and says whether you’re getting it or not. But you still would be coming in two times a week to get an infusion. Patient: Okay. Doctor: That infusion could be real stuff, real vitamin C. Or it could be sugar. Patient: Okay. (Laughs) Doctor: Okay? Huh, so it really is asking a lot of you to give us extra time to sort out whether giving vitamin C makes a difference. Patient: Okay. Doctor: So the theory is vitamin C in high doses may have a, let you have less side effects from the chemotherapy. Huh, at high doses, it may make the chemotherapy work better. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Old data says that sometimes if you take too much vitamin C when you’re getting chemotherapy it could protect the cells, in this case the cancer cells, which we don’t want to protect, and maybe make the chemo work less well. Patient: Okay. Doctor: But have less side effects. Okay? So that’s why we have the dummy pill. Okay? Patient: Okay.

text: Family Member: And the scale - is that improving or not or - Patient: Thirty-eight point six or thirty-eight. Family Member: I don’t know Doctor: It was forty-eight in July. Patient: Right. text: Patient: Okay, Alright. Family Member: Just for the first few days? Doctor: Yeah, they’ll give you like a set time. Oh, yeah, yeah, yeah, and same thing, you know, when you go to the bathroom. It’s the same thing because he doesn’t want to nail you just because you’re sitting next to him it shouldn’t be but, you know, for the younger people or people who are more immunocompromised who are older they get at risk for stuff and we say why bother. Family Member: They won’t put a port in him will they? Doctor: No, we shouldn’t have to. We shouldn’t have to. Family Member: Even though when they get him they go to the Docetaxal? Doctor: Now, Oh, well, from a chemo standpoint we might have to negotiate that. For sure if you get on the high-dose vitamin C one that is more labor intensive because the chemo is once every three months, not three months, once every three weeks. He got hopeful there for a minute. No, sorry, once every three weeks but the vitamin C is twice a week because it’s at such a high dose. Family Member: Oh. Doctor: Well, think about normal stuff you would pop every day you’d almost have to take it multiple times a day to get that dose. This would be the super high one so you’re here like twice a week for like weeks and months. I mean we hope it’s that long because that means it’s working, but yeah, that’s a bit of a slightly draining on that one Patient: Yeah. Doctor: but I have a lot of people who just want their hands on high-dose vitamin C because this is you know, formulated differently than just sort of generic stuff. This is really done with the right, you know, it’s made by a company that’s sort of a spinoff of Hopkins so it’s a very well-regulated product. Um, but, can I tell you that if you’re on placebo you still have to be here? Yeah, because I don’t know who’s getting what. So, the three of us would be fast friends for weeks. Every day it’d be like hello, hello. Just take your name and tape it on an infusion area and you’ll see M____ and S____ all the time. So, that’s one but we’ll work on that. Patient: Okay.

Doctor-Patient-Conversation-Analysis-pos.text: Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.
Doctor-Patient-Conversation-Analysis-pos.displayed_text: Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.
